sen.j: 重箱（じゅうばこ）とは、二重から五重に積み重ねられた、料理を入れる箱である。
sen.e: Jubako is a term used to refer to a box consisting of stacked two to five sub-boxes, in which food is stored.
Jubako is a term used to refer to a box consisting of two to five stacked sub-boxes, in which food is stored.
Jubako is a term used to refer to a box consisting of two to five stacked sub-boxes, in which food is stored.

sen.j: 四季を表す四重が正式とされる。
sen.e: Jubako consisting of four stacked sub-boxes is said to be formal as the number four means the number of seasons.
Jubako consisting of four stacked sub-boxes is said to be formal, as the number four means the number of seasons.
Jubako consisting of four stacked sub-boxes is said to be formal, as the number four means the number of seasons.

sen.j: 四段目は四の字忌避で「与の重」と呼ぶ。
sen.e: The fourth sub-box is called as "Yo-no-ju" instead of "Shi-no-ju" because the pronunciation of "Shi" is the same as that of "死 (death)."
The fourth sub-box is called "Yo-no-ju" instead of "Shi-no-ju" because the pronunciation of "Shi" is the same as that of "死 (death)."
The fourth sub-box is called 'Yo-no-ju' instead of "Shi-no-ju" because the pronunciation of "Shi" is the same as that of "死 (death)."
sen.cmt: 原文の「」のところに' 'を付加しました。

sen.j: 形状は四角が一般的であるが、円形や六角形、八角形のものもある。
sen.e: While typical Jubako has a rectangular shape, some of them have a circular shape, a hexagonal shape, or an octagonal shape.
While typical Jubako has a rectangular shape, some of them have a circular shape, a hexagonal shape, or an octagonal shape.
While typical Jubako has a rectangular shape, some of them have a circular shape, a hexagonal shape, or an octagonal shape.

sen.j: 今日では主に、正月の御節料理、花見や運動会などの弁当、また、鰻重の容器に使われる。
sen.e: Nowadays, Jubako are normally used to store Osechi-ryori on the New Years' Day, are used as a lunch box for cherry blossom viewing or sporting events, or are used as a container for Unaju (a boxed rice and roast eel).

Nowadays, Jubako are normally used to store Osechi-ryori on New Years' Day, are used as a lunch box for cherry blossom viewing or sporting events, or are used as a container for Unaju (boxed rice and roast eel).
Nowadays, Jubako are normally used to store Osechi-ryori on New Years' Day, or as a lunch box for cherry blossom viewing or sporting events, or as a container for Unaju (boxed rice and roast eel).
sen.cmt: 一部、翻訳を変更しました。

sen.j: 室町時代の文献の中に既に「重箱」の記述を見ることができるので、その歴史はかなり古いと考えられる。
sen.e: The history of Jubako is considered to be rather long because the term Jubako can be found in literatures in the Muromachi period.
The history of Jubako is considered to be rather long because the term Jubako can be found in literature from the Muromachi period.
The history of Jubako is considered to be rather long because the term 'Jubako' can be found in literature from the Muromachi period.
sen.cmt: 原文の「」のところに' 'を付加しました。

sen.j: 一般庶民に普及したのは江戸時代（1610年）で、本格的に重箱が製造されてからである。
sen.e: Jubako became popular among ordinary people in the Edo period when their commercial production began in 1610.
Jubako became popular among ordinary people in the Edo period when their commercial production began in 1610.
Jubako became popular among ordinary people in the Edo period when their commercial production began in 1610.

sen.j: 武家や大名のもとでは、漆塗や蒔絵の豪華なものも作られた。
sen.e: Gorgeous Jubako, such as those coated with Urushi lacquer and those decorated by Makie, were also made for Samurai and Daimyo classes.
Gorgeous Jubako, such as those coated with Urushi lacquer and those decorated by Makie, were also made for Samurai and Daimyo classes.
Gorgeous Jubako, such as those coated with Urushi lacquer and those decorated by Makie, were also made for Samurai and Daimyo classes.

sen.j: また、狩りなどに出かけるときに持ち運びに便利なものも使用された。
sen.e: Potable Jubako, which are convenient to be carried for hunting and other outdoor events, were also used.
Potable Jubako, which are convenient to be carried for hunting and other outdoor events, were also used.
Potable Jubako, which are convenient to be carried for hunting and other outdoor events, were also used.

sen.j: 最近は、ポリプロピレンなどの新素材による容器（いわゆる弁当箱）が普及し、目にする機会は次第に少なくなってきている。
sen.e: Recently, Jubako are not used as often as they used to be because containers (or lunch boxes) made of new materials, such as polypropylene, etc., are in widespread use.
Recently, Jubako are not used as often as they used to be because containers (or lunch boxes) made of new materials, such as polypropylene, etc., are in widespread use.
Recently, Jubako are not used as often as they used to be because containers (or lunch boxes) made of new materials, such as polypropylene, etc., are in widespread use.

sen.j: 中国の食籠（じきろう、六角形や八角形の重ねて使用する容器）が語源。
sen.e: The origin of Jubako is "Jikiro" of China, which is a hexagonal or octagonal container consisting of stacked sub-boxes.
The origin of Jubako is "Jikiro" of China, which is a hexagonal or octagonal container consisting of stacked sub-boxes.
The origin of Jubako is "Jikiro" of China, which is a hexagonal or octagonal container consisting of stacked sub-boxes.

sen.j: 木製の物や漆器、合成樹脂などの素材で作られることが多い。
sen.e: Jubako are often made of materials, such as wood (some of them are coated with Urushi lacquer), synthetic resin, etc.
Jubako are often made of materials such as wood (some of them are coated with Urushi lacquer), synthetic resin, etc.
Jubako are often made of materials such as wood (some of them are coated with Urushi lacquer), synthetic resin, etc.

sen.j: なかには紙製のものや、陶磁器で作られたものなどもある。
sen.e: Some of them are made of paper or ceramic.
Some of them are made of paper or ceramic.
Some of them are made of paper or ceramic.

sen.j: 美術品としては尾形光琳の「蒔絵梅椿若松図重箱」などが有名。
sen.e: Makie-baichin-wakamatuzu-jubako by Korin OGATA is famous as one of artistic Jubako.
Makie-baichin-wakamatuzu-jubako by Korin OGATA is famous as an example of artistic Jubako.
Makie-baichin-wakamatuzu-jubako by Korin OGATA is famous as an example of artistic Jubako.

sen.j: 漆器で作られた重箱はその産地により、名称が異なる。
sen.e: Urushi lacquered Jubako are called by different names depending on their producing district.
Urushi lacquered Jubako are called by different names depending on their producing district.
Urushi lacquered Jubako are called by different names depending on their producing district.

sen.j: 重箱の隅を楊子で穿（ほじ）くる。
sen.e: "Jubako no sumi wo yoji de hojikuru" (Nitpicking)
"Jubako no sumi wo yoji de hojikuru" (Nitpicking)
"Jubako no sumi wo yoji de hojikuru" (Nitpicking)

sen.j: 重箱の隅を穿くる（「重箱の隅をつつく」ともいう）。
sen.e: "Jubako no sumi wo hojikuru" or "Jubako no sumi wo tsutsuku" (Nitpicking)
"Jubako no sumi wo hojikuru" or "Jubako no sumi wo tsutsuku" (Nitpicking)
"Jubako no sumi wo hojikuru" or "Jubako no sumi wo tsutsuku" (Nitpicking) (make a fuss over details)
